Table 4 Catalyst FK Conv.% BAPF PFI Select.% Ea (kJ/mol) R 2 Select.% Ea (kJ/mol) R 2 HPW/Mt 99.2 70.2 135.7 0.9558 29.8 35.8 0.9916 Mn0.5HPW/Mt 99.1 79.4 128.8 0.9393 20.6 42.4 0.9409 Mn1HPW/Mt 99.1 83.4 130.5 0.9346 16.6 44.9 0.9278 Mn1.5HPW/Mt 88.2 65.7 148.8 0.9853 34.3 44.1 0.9722 Perspective Mn modified phosphotungstic acid, a highly selective catalyst for the synthesis of 9, 9-bis (4-aminophenyl) fluorene Chen Hu Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Validation Writing – original draft Jianfeng An Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Validation Yufan Xie Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Zhiyong Zhang Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Resources ⁎ School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Polytechnic University, Wuhan 430023, PR China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Polytechnic University Wuhan 430023 PR China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Polytechnic University, Wuhan 430023, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. 9,9-Bis (4-aminophenyl) fluorene (BAPF) has been widely used in the research of high-performance polyimide and fluorene-based optical materials. However, it is challenging to mass production due to the limitation of catalytic technology. In this paper, various Mn exchanged phosphotungstic acid supported on montmorillonite catalysts were prepared. FESEM-EDX, FT-IR, Raman, XRD, XPS, BET, and NH3-TPD were deployed to characterize the catalyst material. BAPF, synthesized by 9-fluorenone and aniline, was used to evaluate the catalytic activities of catalysts under different conditions. The amount and strength of acid sites were changed by the number of Mn ions into phosphotungstic acid, which affected the catalytic activity of BAPF synthesis. The findings of this study show that the yield of BAPF can reach up to 82.9%. In addition, the catalyst can maintain a high catalytic activity after three times of recycling, which can effectively simplify the purification process and reduce the environmental footprint of BAPF manufacturing. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Phosphotungstic acid Montmorillonite Heterogeneous catalyst Keggin structure Surface acid sites BAPF synthesis 1 Introduction 9,9-Bis(4-aminophenyl)fluoren (BAPF) is a popular compound for developing high-performance functional material in recent years. Owing to the strong stability π-electron conjugated system and rigid molecular chain of BAPF [1], BAPF based compounds, such as polyimide (PI), can exhibit not only excellent mechanical properties, dielectric properties, optical properties [2,3], but also has strong resistance over extreme temperature [4], radiation, and chemical corrosion [5] as well as other favorable characteristics. Those compounds have been widely used in aerospace [2], microelectronics [3], nanomaterials [5], laser [6] and wearable electronic devices [7,8], etc. The synthesis of BAPF using 9-fluorenone (FK) and aniline as raw materials and concentrated sulfuric acid as catalyst and 3-mercaptopropionic acid as cocatalyst has been successfully applied in small-scale industrial production [46]. However, the synthesis of BAPF involving undesirable competing reaction ( Scheme 1) that produce by-products, such as N-phenyl-9H-fluoren-9-imine (PFI), resulting in poor selectivity of BAPF and difficulty in purification during production. In particular, their inherent drawbacks to using liquid acid as homogeneous catalysts, such as the high cost of separating the acid from the reaction solution and the generation of massive acid wastewater [9]. This production process can incur significant production costs as well as high environmental footprint, making it impractical for BAPF to achieve large-scale industrial production. Notably, this is also one of the impeding factors to develop downstream products such as PI. Therefore, it is imperative to develop new catalysts to improve the selectivity and yield of BAPF synthesis with minimal environmental impact. Recently, several catalysts have been proposed for the synthesis of BAPF, such as aniline hydrochloride [10], ion exchange resin [11], sulfated zirconia [12] etc. However, these catalysts are still unsuitable for large scale production due to the high consumption of catalyst, difficulty of recycling, and high environment footprint. Notably, heteropoly acid (HPA) has been proposed by Yu et al. [17] as a novel catalyst for BAPF synthesis. HPA is a new type of solid acid catalyst that has been widely used in esterification [13], transesterification [14], selective oxidation [15], and Friedel–Crafts acylation [16] due to its strong Bronsted acidity and special catalytic properties. However, it was difficult to remove HPA after partial dissolution in aniline, and the problem of reaction selectivity was still not solved. thereby remains unsatisfied and challenged for the actual production. The activity of solid acid catalysis for the synthesis of BAPF is strongly dependent on the accessibility of reactants to active sites, and the number, strength, and type (Bronsted and Lewis) of acid site. Hiroki et al. [18] reported that Lewis acid site was beneficial to improving the catalytic activity of the synthesis of 9,9–Bis[4–(2–hydroxyethoxy)phenyl]fluorene. Omata et al. [16] introduced a series of transition metal ions into the secondary structure of phosphotungstic acid. They found that Pt4+ and Mn2+ not only changed the number and strength of Bronstic acid sites, but also improved the activity of the catalyst in electrophilic substitution reaction. Different supports such as activated carbon [19], mesoporous silica [20], zeolite [21] and montmorillonite [22] have been reported to support heteropoly acids. Montmorillonite, a lamellar aluminosilicate, is easy to obtain in nature. Using acid activated montmorillonite can increase its interlayer gap, expand the specific surface area and provide more loading sites [23]. To date, there are no reports that can address the challenge of catalytic activity. of BAPF synthesis using HPW modified by transition metal ions. In this work, Mn2+ ions with different contents were introduced into HPW and dispersed uniformly on acid activated montmorillonite to form a heterogeneous catalyst. In this study, the catalytic activity, selectivity, and recoverability of the proposed catalysts were characterized in reaction. The work of this paper is not only to optimize the production process of BAPF by using new catalysts, improve atomic economy, reduce pollution emissions, and make it have the potential of industrial application. On this basis, the characterization results of the catalyst were further correlated with the catalytic activity, and the basic structure-activity relationship between the number and strength of acid sites and the reactivity and selectivity of the catalyst was discussed, which provided experimental materials and ideas for the design of new catalysts in the subsequent work. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals 9-Fluorenone (C13H8O, 99.5%), Phosphotungstic acid hydrate (H3PW12O40·xH2O, AR), 3-Mercaptopropionic acid (C3H6O2S, 99%), K-10 montmorillonite were purchased from the Aladdin. Manganese acetate (C4H6MnO4.4H2O, AR), Anhydrous ethanol (C2H5OH, AR) and Acetonitrile (CH3CN, GC) purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co Ltd. Aniline (C6H5NH2, AR), Chlorobenzene (C6H5Cl, AR), Hydrochloric acid solution (10 mol/L HCl, AR) was purchased from Tianjin Damao Reagent Chemical Co Ltd, aniline is purified by distillation before use. 2.2 Synthesis catalyst The montmorillonite was activated by hydrochloric acid, add 600 ml of 5 mol/L hydrochloric acid solution and 80 g of K10 montmorillonite into a 1 L round bottomed flask, heat at 120 ℃ under fast stirring and refluxed for two hours. After cooling, the solution was centrifuged, the supernatant was poured out, washed filter residue with deionized water and centrifuged several times. When the liquid filtered was free of Cl– (testing with the solution of 5%wt AgNO3) [24]. Place the filter residue in the vacuum drying oven and set the temperature at 120 ℃ to dry overnight obtained acid activated montmorillonite (Mt). The surplus free water and crystal water in hydrated phosphotungstic acid were removed by using Muffle Furnace at 200 ℃ for two hours to obtain H3PW12O40.6H2O (referred to as HPW). Manganese was doped into HPW by the method reported in literature [25]. The required quantity of HPW dissolved in a minimum amount of deionized water and a calculated amount of aqueous Manganese acetate solution was added dropwise. The resulting mixture was aged for one hour at 80 °C. Then the water was evaporated to dryness by rotary evaporator, and the solid residual was calcined in Muffle Furnace at 300 ℃ for two hours to obtain manganese substituted proton heteropoly acid (MnxH3–2xPW12O40, hereinafter referred to as MnxHPW, x = 0.5, 1 and 1.5). To dissolve MnxHPW in a small amount of ethanol, and heat it to 50 ℃, according to the weight ratio of MnxHPW: Mt = 1: 4 to be added Mt, stir vigorously for 24 h. and then removal of ethanol by rotary distillation. The obtained solid was calcined at 300 ℃ for 3 h in Muffle Furnace to obtain the catalyst sample of MnxHPW/Mt. 2.3 Materials characterizations Samples of all catalysts were dried at 100 ℃ for 3 h before any experiment and characterization to remove water and gaseous impurities. Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM) were obtained using a Ziess Sigma 500 microscope to observe the morphology of the prepared samples. The elemental distribution of materials was determined using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) of Bruker. The infrared spectra (IR) were collected from Nicolet 330 spectrometer using potassium bromide tableting method. The scanning range was 4000–400 cm−1. Each spectrum was obtained by an average of 32 scans with a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. In order to explore the properties of the acid sites (Bronsted acid and Lewis acid) of the catalysts, the diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) mode was deployed by Thermo Fisher Nicolet is50 spectrometer for pyridine adsorption studies. The catalyst sample was vacuum dried at 150 °C for one hour, and then was mixed with excessive pyridine. The physically adsorbed pyridine was removed by vacuum treatment, and the infrared spectrum was recorded at this temperature. Confocal Raman spectra in the range of 100–1200 cm−1 were recorded by Lab RAM HR Evolution Raman spectrometer with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm, power 100 mW, and 600lines/mm grating. The testing time is 10 s for each acquisition. Each acquisition is repeated for 10 times. Using Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer, Cu-Kα radiation (0.154056 nm) was used at 40 kV and 40 mA for X-ray diffraction measurement. The scanning range was 5–90° (2 θ) and the scanning speed was 5°/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was tested by Thermo Scientific K-alpha instrument. Using Al-Kα ray (1486.6ev), the sample chamber was in high vacuum. Data of narrow spectrum were obtained by multiple scanning. C1s was used as a reference to calibrate the deviation of binding energy, and C1s was calibrated to 284.80 eV. The catalysts were tested on ASAP-2460 automatic nitrogen adsorption desorption analyzer. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface areas. The total pore volume was determined by the adsorbed amount of N2 at a relative pressure of P/P0 = 0.95. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 was performed on AutoChem II 2920. Sample was pretreated at 300 °C for 2 h by flowing helium gas (99.9%, 30 ml/min). When the temperature was cooled to 50 ℃, the mixture of 10% NH3 and 90% He was introduced for adsorption for 1 h, and the physically adsorbed ammonia is cleaned with flowing helium (30 ml/min, 1 h) at the same temperature. The temperature programmed desorption test was carried out in the range of 50–700 ℃, and the heating rate was 10 ℃/min. The amount of NH3 adsorbed was calculated using the calibrated thermal conductivity detector based on the TCD signals. The number and strength of acid sites on the surface of catalyst can be determined by n-butylamine titration. About 200 mg of catalyst powder was suspended in 30 ml of acetonitrile (dried with 4A molecular sieve), vibrated by ultrasound for one hour, and stirred at 25 °C for two hours. Then potentiometric titration was carried out with acetonitrile solution of 0.0025 mol/L n-butylamine. The change of electrode potential was monitored by LeiCi ZD-2 potentiometric titrator. The initial electrode potential was acid strength. The amount of acid sites on the catalyst surface was calculated based on the volume of n-butylamine solution consumed. 2.4 Catalytic performance assessment 9 g (0.05 mol) FK, 20 ml chlorobenzene, 0.45 g 3-mercaptopropionic acid, and a certain amount of catalyst were added into a 100 ml three-port flask. Typically, a predetermined amount of aniline was added into a constant pressure dropping funnel. The three-port flask was connected with a water segregator and a nitrogen-supplying device. Oil bathing was carried out by a DF-101s heater with constant stirring. When the temperature reached the designated temperature and remained constant, aniline was added as continuous drops for about 20 min. and start to timekeeping after aniline is added complete. After the reaction reaches the designated time, the catalyst was removed by suction filtration, and the reaction solution was dissolved in acetonitrile (GC). The results were analyzed by Agilent 1260 II high performance liquid chromatography using standard curve method. FK Conversion (%) = (1-moles of FK/moles of starting FK) × 100% BAPF Selectivity (%) = moles of BAPF / (moles of starting FK × FK Conversion (%)) × 100% BAPF Yield (%) = FK conversion × BAPF Selectivity × 100% 2.5 Reusability of catalyst The recycling and reusing experiment was conducted upon the completion of reaction. The catalyst was recovered by suction filtration from the reaction solution. The collected catalyst was rinsed with acetone and then was centrifuged to remove acetone residues, repeating thrice in total. Lastly, the sample was dried overnight in a 100 ℃ vacuum oven. The same reaction was repeated thrice using the recovered catalyst under the same conditions, during which fresh catalyst was only added to compensate the minor loss during recovery. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst 3.1.1 FESEM-EDX analysis The surface morphology and microstructure of Mt and Mn1HPW/Mt were studied by FESEM. Both materials showed the typical lamellar structure. The lamellae of Mt are relatively disordered, and the surface of the lamellae was coarse ( Fig. 1-a.b.c). Acidification treatment can remove the interlayer cations, and thereby reduce the intermolecular force between layers [23]. As a consequence, the interlayers were stripped into small pieces with micro cracks on their surfaces. After loading Mt with Mn1HPW, it can be observed in Fig. 1-d.e.f that the lamellar structure of Mn1HPW was orderly arranged in the plane, and the lamellar surface became relatively smooth. This may be due to the adsorption of Mn1HPW on the surface of Mt during the loading process. Mn1HPW was uniformly distributed and crystallized on the surface of montmorillonite, filling tiny cracks and smoothing the surface of montmorillonite lamellar [26]. This hypothesis is also supported by the decrease of specific surface area after loading. Mn1HPW was loaded between the layers of montmorillonite, which increased the force between the layers and rearrange the layers orderly in the plane [27]. In order to further confirm this understanding, EDX analysis was carried out to obtain the element distribution on sample surface. As shown in Fig. 2-a, Mt has the characteristic fluorescence of silicon and aluminum, but no characteristic fluorescence of manganese and tungsten. The characteristic fluorescence of trace phosphorus is due to the sample surface spraying platinum, and the energy of platinum and phosphorus is close in the spectrum, creating interference. After loading Mn1HPW, the characteristic fluorescence of these five elements, clearly presented in Fig. 2-b, demonstrated that this loading method can successfully create a uniform distribution of Mn1HPW. 3.1.2 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) The infrared spectra in Fig. 3 show that both HPW and MnxHPW exhibited characteristic peaks at 3430, 1613, 1078, 981, 892, 809, and 523 cm−1. The peaks at 3430 cm−1 and 1613 cm−1 are OH stretching vibration and HOH bending vibration, respectively. Both signals indicate the presence of the binding water of heteropoly acid molecules. The 1078 cm−1 peak refers to the stretching vibration of PO bond, and 523 cm−1 the bending vibration of OPO bond in the central PO4 tetrahedron. In WO6 octahedron, the absorption bands of WOW appear at 892 cm−1 and 809 cm−1. The 981 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibration of WO (t-terminal oxygen). These characteristic signals demonstrate the Keggin structure of HPW, which remained intact after the introduction of Mn [28]. In the sample containing Mt, 1100 cm−1 is the asymmetric stretching vibration of silicon oxygen bond, 473 cm−1 is the bending vibration of OSiO, 565 cm−1 is the Si-O-Al-Si vibration between the silicon oxide layer and the aluminum oxide layer [29]. The characteristic peaks of Keggin structure and montmorillonite structure were retained in Mn1HPW/Mt. However, compared with MnxHPW, the characteristic peaks of Keggin structure were obviously weakened. These spectral differences indicate that Keggin anionic group has strong interaction with montmorillonite [30], which can reduce the desorption of catalytic active sites in recycling. 3.1.3 Infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption Generally speaking, the characteristic peak near 1542 cm−1 indicate the occurrence of Bronsted acid site, and the characteristic peak near 1456 cm−1 suggested the presence of Lewis acid site [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 4, HPW/Mt showed only characteristic peaks related to Bronsted acid sites. After the introduction of manganese ions, the characteristic peaks related to Lewis acid sites appeared in the catalyst, and the intensity of the characteristic peaks around 1456 cm−1 gradually increased with the increase of manganese content. This pattern indicates introducing manganese ion can promote the presence of Lewis acid sites due to the presence of Mn ions into the secondary structure of the heteropoly tungstate [33]. Although it has been reported that there are a few acid sites in acid activated montmorillonite [23]. However, no noticeable absorption peak was observed from the montmorillonite. The absence of montmorillonite peak may be caused by the weak acidity of montmorillonite, which can be desorbed with pyridine at the temperature below 150 ℃. 3.1.4 Laser Raman spectroscopic In Fig. 5-a, the strong absorption peak at 1009 cm−1 can be attributed to the PO stretching vibration of the central phosphorus atom, and the peak at 990 cm−1 can be assigned to the WO (t-terminal oxygen) Tensile vibration. The broad Raman bands at 905 cm−1 and 527 cm−1 corresponded to asymmetric stretching vibrations of WOW (Angle sharing oxygen atom) and symmetric stretching vibrations of WOW (Edge sharing oxygen atom). The bands at 230 cm−1 and 148 cm−1 indicate WOW bending vibrations. The peak at 216 cm−1 may be related to the coupling of these two bending vibrations [34]. These Raman characteristic signals also confirmed the presence of Keggin structure of MnxHPW. It can be observed that by increasing Mn content the absorption peak at 905 cm−1 gradually moves to the direction of high wave number, which indicates that manganese ion was started to be introduced into the secondary structure of phosphotungstic acid and interacts with [PW12O40]3- anion. As a result, the volume of Keggin unit was expanded, promoting the protonation of crystal water [33]. Due to the low polarizability of SiO, there is usually no obvious absorption peak in the Raman spectrum of montmorillonite (Fig. 5-b). The absorption peak at 137 cm−1 is related to the ring vibration of SiO [35]. It can be seen that the Raman signal intensity of Keggin structure decreases obviously after loading Mn1HPW on montmorillonite, which indicates that Mn1HPW is uniformly distributed on the Mt. 3.1.5 X-ray diffraction patterns Fig. 6-a shows the XRD pattern of catalyst MnxHPW, the presence of Keggin structure of HPW was confirmed by the diffraction peaks of HPW at 10.2°, 17.9°, 21.4°, 25.3°, and 37.6°, combined with the characteristic peaks of 14.2°, 23.8°, 29.2°, and 34.3°, it shows that HPW has been calcined at 473k to remove the excess crystal water and form H3PW12O40.6H2O [36]. It can be observed in Fig. 6-b that the intensity of the diffraction peak at 10.2° and 21.4° decreased and a new diffraction peak appeared at a lower angle (9.1° and 20.2°), while the intensity of the diffraction peak at 25.3° decreased and a new diffraction peak appeared at a higher angle (26.9°). The results show that Mn has been doped into the secondary structure of phosphotungstic acid during the preparation of the catalyst, which leads to the expansion of Keggin-type heteropolyanion [37]. This observation is consistent with the results of Raman spectroscopy. In the spectra of montmorillonite samples, 16.2°, 28.4°, 35.1°, and 41.8° corresponded to (002) (004) (105) and (044) crystal planes respectively. The broad peak near 21° was attributed by amorphous silica. The rest diffraction peaks can be assigned to the mixed aluminosilicate structure of feldspar, quartz and pyroxene [22]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of MnxHPW and montmorillonite were also exhibited by sample Mn1HPW/Mt, which indicated that Mn1HPW, as the catalytic active site, occurred on the Mt surface. 3.1.6 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer XPS can reveal the element composition and structural information in detail. As shown in Fig. 7-a, the characteristic peaks of P2p, O1s, W4p, W4d and W4f appeared in HPW, which confirmed the existence of these elements. The characteristic peak of Mn2p orbital also appears in Mn1HPW, which indicates that manganese has been successfully introduced into HPW. The XPS spectrum of O1s can be represented by two peaks (Fig. 7-b). The peaks at 531.1 eV and 530.6 eV are related to WOW, and the peaks at 532.4 eV and 531.5 eV are related to PO4 [38]. The spectrum of W4f is shown in Fig. 7-c: the peaks of 37.9 eV and 37.5 eV are W4f 5/2, and the peaks of 35.7eVand 35.5 eV are W4f 7/2. The binding energy for W4f 7/2 is approximately equal to that of W6+. This chemical structure of tungsten can be attributed to the tungsten oxygen octahedron in Keggin unit [39]. The spectra of Mn2p as shown in Fig. 7-d gives a satellite peak at 647.0 eV, a distinct signature of Mn (II). As shown in Fig. 7-e, the binding energy of P2p decreased from 134.5 eV to 134.1 eV. The phenomenon that the binding energy decreases slightly also appears in O1s and W4f, this change is due to the electron transfer from manganese ion to HPW, increasing the proton mobility and the acid strength of the catalyst [22,40,41]. 3.1.7 Adsorption–desorption isotherm and BET surface area In order to research the porosity and specific surface area of the catalysts, their nitrogen adsorption desorption isotherms were measured as shown in Fig. 8. According to the BDDT classification, Mt has type IV isotherms and hysteresis loops is similar to type H2 (a). There are some steeps occurred in the desorption curve, which are related to the blockage of narrow pore necks or evaporation induced by cavitation effect [42]. It has been reported that unacidated montmorillonite usually shows H3 type hysteresis loop. After acid treatment, the cations of octahedron in montmorillonite were removed. The complex of pore network was formed due to the loosened layer structures and or certain structural deformations [23]. Type IV isotherm and type H3 hysteresis loop appear in Mn1HPW/Mt samples. No saturated adsorption plateau was observed in the high pressure region, which is a typical feature of nonrigid lamellar materials and mesoporous materials. Pure Mn1HPW exhibited a type III isotherm with no obvious hysteresis loop. The concave curve was due to the intermolecular force between adsorbate is greater than that between adsorbent and adsorbate molecules, making it difficult for adsorption. The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst are shown in Table 1. The specific surface area of Mn1HPW powder is 6.5 m2/g without obvious pore structure. The specific surface area and pore volume of Mt are 258.2 m2/g and 0.41 cm3/g respectively. After loading Mn1HPW onto Mt, the specific surface area of sample decreased to 143.3 m2/g and its pore volume changed to 0.22 cm3/g. Combining the data of BET and SEM-EDX, this reduction on both specific surface area and pore volume can be caused by the tight aggregation of Mn1HPW on the surface and in the pores of Mt, blocking pore structures and hindering the mobility of nitrogen molecules [43]. This postulate also explained the change of hysteresis type before and after the loading: larger specific surface area and pore volume can make the catalytic active sites evenly distributed on the supporting Mt, increasing the contact probability with the substrate and the reaction efficiency. 3.1.8 Measurement of the number and strength of acid sites in catalysts The acidity of MnxHPW/Mt was measured by NH3-TPD. Typically, the desorption of ammonia at 50–250 ℃ corresponds to weak acid sites, desorption at 250–450 ℃ corresponds to moderate acids, and desorption at 450–700 ℃ corresponds to strong acid sites. Fig. 9(a) shows that sample HPW/Mt only exhibited a strong peak around 580 °C, indicating the presence of strong acid site. According to the research, the high temperature desorption peak of HPW typically corresponds to the Bronsted site instead of the Lewis acid sites. With the addition of Mn ions, the desorption peak at low temperature region became apparent and continually strengthened as the amount of Mn content increased. Given the observation from Py-IR, the desorption peak at low temperature should correspond to the Lewis acid site, which is related to the d orbital of Mn [44]. Due to the small size of ammonia molecule, ammonia can easily enter the Keggin unit, which makes the NH3-TPD test result usually be the total number of acid sites of heteropoly acid catalyst. Therefore, n-butylamine titration method is still needed to calculate the number and strength of acid sites on the catalyst surface (Acid sites actually involved in the reaction). Table 2 shows that when the coefficient of Mn ion content increased from 0 to 1, not only the number of acid sites of the catalyst was increased, but also the acid strength was enhanced. However, when the coefficient of Mn was near 1.5, both the number of acid sites and acid strength of the catalyst decreased, yet there are still a lot of Bronsted acid sites. These patterns indicate that 1) there are at least two kinds of unequal protons in HPW, and 2) the process that introduced Mn ions to phosphotungstic acid was more complicated than ion-exchange. According to previous reports, when transition metal ions are introduced into the secondary structure of heteropoly tungstate, they can affect the interaction between the unsaturated W6+ site and crystal water, promoting the protonation of water and the formation of Bronsted acid sites [31,45]. The acid strength of heteropoly acid is directly correlated to the proton conductivity. The presence of transition metal ions in the heteropoly acid can improve both the proton mobility and the acid strength of the catalyst [22,41]. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic activity of MnxHPW/Mt was evaluated by synthesizing BAPF from aniline and FK (with a molar ratio of aniline to FK 5:1) under three different temperatures: 130 ℃, 140 ℃ and 150 ℃. The results (Table. S1) show that among MnxHPW/Mt Mn1HPW/Mt gave the highest yield at any given reaction temperatures aforementioned. Fig. 10-a,b show the effect of catalyst on the selectivity of synthetic BAPF at different stages of the reaction. The results show that among MnxHPW/Mt Mn1HPW/Mt gave the highest selectivity. Fig. 10-c shows that when using Mn1HPW/Mt under 130 ℃, the reaction had not reach equilibrium within 11 h, In addition, the yield of BAPF was 50.1%, which gave the FK conversion rate 87.6 and the selectivity of BAPF 57.9%. When the temperature was increased to 140 ℃, the reaction reached equilibrium in about 9 h, and the yield of BAPF was significantly improved with a conversion rate of FK 99.4% and the selectivity of BAPF 83.4%. When the reaction temperature was 150 ℃, the reaction reached equilibrium in 7 h with the yield of BAPF comparable to those of 140 ℃. The increment of BAPF selectivity was at the expense of reduced PFI selectivity since the syntheses of BAPF and PFI are two competing reactions. Notably, increasing temperature can improve the selectivity of BAPF. However, even under the flowing nitrogen, aniline can still be oxidized at 150 ℃, which makes it difficult to purify the product. Therefore, for the purpose of practical applications, the standard reaction condition were at 140 ℃ for 9 h. The effect of different amount of catalyst on the reaction is shown in Fig. 11-a. With the increase of catalyst amount, the conversion rate of FK and the selectivity of BAPF were improved. When the amount of catalyst reaches 14 wt% or higher, the conversion rate of FK was close to 100%, but the selectivity of BAPF was not significantly improved. Fig. 11-b shows that initial formation rate of BAPF was increased linearly with the increment of catalyst dosage, whereas the formation rate of PFI remained steady. This phenomenon was dictated by the number of acid sites on the surface of the catalyst that directly control the formation rate of BAPF, but may not exert similar impact on the formation process of PFI. At 14 wt% catalyst, the yield rate of BAPF was favorable reaching 82.9%. Therefore, the optimal catalyst dosage would be 14 wt%. To study the effect of molar ratio of reactants on the reaction, only the aniline dosage was varied to adjust the aniline to FK molar ratio while the rest reaction conditions remained unchanged. As shown in Fig. 12-a, a series of recactions with molar ratios of aniline to FK ranging from 2:1–6:1 was performed, which shows that increasing aniline dosage can improve both the conversion rate of FK and the selectivity of BAPF. In Fig. 12-b, with the increase of molar ratio from 2:1–4:1, the formation rate of BAPF was increased significantly, whereas the formation rate of PFI was increased slightly. High concentration of aniline is beneficial to improve the contact probability between reactants and catalytic active sites. However, when the molar ratio was greater than 5:1, the formation rate and yield of BAPF were only slightly increased, reaching plateau. When the molar ratio of aniline to FK was 5:1, the yield of BAPF was approaching the maximum. Therefore, a molar ratio of 5:1 would be optimal for the purpose of mass production since the generated waste and the environmental impact would be minimized. 3.3 Reusability and heterogeneity of catalysts Reusable catalyst can not only reduce the environmental footprint, but also effectively cut production costs. The process of catalyst recovery consists of several steps, including filtration, washing, centrifugation, etc. Typically, each usage would incur ~10% weight loss in catalyst, which needs to be refilled periodically. In this study, the catalyst reusability was assessed by reusing the catalyst thrice under the proposed reaction conditions: 14 wt% Mn1HPW/Mt and 5:1 molar ratio of aniline to FK under 140 °C for 9 h. As shown in Fig. 13-a, the conversion rate of FK decreases from 99.4% to 89.7% in the first recycling, to 83.6% in the second one, and to 84.2% in the third one. Compared with the pristine sample, the selectivity of the recovered catalyst for BAPF did not decrease significantly, only from 83.4% to 80.9%. The reused catalyst was characterized by various techniques. In Fig. S1, the typical lamellar structure of catalyst can be observed, and there is still obvious characteristic fluorescence of these five elements in EDX image, indicating that the microscopic morphology of the catalyst does not change significantly after recycling. In the FT-IR and XRD pattern (Fig. S2-S3), the reused catalyst still retained characteristic peaks related to Keggin structure and montmorillonite, consistent with the fresh catalyst. The specific surface area of the reused catalyst did not change significantly (143.3 m3/g to 140.7 m3/g), and the number of acid sites decreased slightly from 0.768 mmol/g to 0.744 mmol/g (weak:0.213 mmol/g, moderate:0.175 mmol/g, strong:0.356 mmol/g) (Fig. S4). This minor change may be due to the desorption between the active sites and the support material during the reaction and catalyst recovery, which reduces the conversion efficiency of BAPF in new reactions. It is also possible that certain impurity compounds can have strong interaction with the catalytic active sites, such as occupying the active center in the new reaction and reducing the catalytic efficiency. Those impurity could be difficult to remove in the recovery process. Nonetheless, the overall catalytic performance of the recovered catalyst was comparable with the pristine one. To evaluate the heterogeneity of the catalyst, a hot filtration experment was carried out with Mn1HPW on Montmorillonite. As shown in Fig. 13-b, the yield of BAPF is 27.9% when it was heated for two hours under the optimal reaction conditions. Then, the reaction mixture was hot filtered, and all catalysts were separated. Upon the removal of reacted solids, the reaction solution was heated for additional 4 h. And the final yield of BAPF was 28.5%. Apparently, increment in yield was hardly noticeable, indicating that the amount of catalyst leached in the reacted solution was insubstantial. This hot filtration experiment shows that the catalyst is primarily residing in the solids and therefore its activity is of heterogeneous nature. Table 3. 3.4 Comparison with other catalysts The activity of Mn1HPW/Mt and other catalysts in the synthesis of BAPF are compared in Table 4. When the mixture of montmorillonite and Mn1HPW was used as catalyst, the yield of BAPF was only 43.6%. This indicates that Mn1HPW was uniformly dispersed on the surface of montmorillonite, which was also supported by the low minimal catalyst dosage. The low minimal catalyst dosage that can form majority of active sites confirmed the success of this supported method. In terms of yield and cost of BAPF synthesis, the proposed catalyst in this study is superior to the common catalysts, such as H2SO4, C6H5NH2·HCl, and Amberlyst-15. The yield by H2SO4 was relatively low, only 58%. Whereas the yield by C6H5NH2·HCl can reach 87.8%, but with 300 wt% catalyst dosage and under temperature over 160 °C. Most importantly, using either H2SO4 or C6H5NH2·HCl would produce a substantial amount of acid-water, which inevitably would pose a great risk to the environment. When Amberlyst-15 (ion exchange resin) was selected as catalyst, the yield could reach 71.4%. However, it is still challenging to deactivate Amberlyst-15 in production. Therefore, all these catalysts would impose a high cost on industrial production. The proposed Mn1HPW/Mt can effectively address those issues due to its high catalytic activity and recycling ability in these catalysts, demonstrating excellent potential for industrial applications. 3.5 Effects of acid sites number and acid strength on reaction activity To further understand the impact of catalyst composition on the activity, effect of manganese ion content on catalytic activity was investigated by calculating the apparent activation energy, the initial formation rates of BAPF and PFI in chemical reaction were selected, and the apparent activation energies of BAPF and PFI generated by different catalysts were preliminarily estimated by using Arrhenius empirical formula (The second hour, following is consistent with it). As shown in Fig. 14-a,b and Table 4, HPW/Mt catalyst gave the apparent activation energy 135.7 kJ/mol and 35.8 kJ/mol for the formation of BAPF and PFI, respectively. MnxHPW/Mt with x at 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5 exhibited apparent activation energies for formation of BAPF 128.5 kJ/mol, 130.5 kJ/mol, and 148.8 kJ/mol, respectively. The different apparent activation energy incurred by difference in Mn content in MnxHPW/Mt can explain the impact of Mn content on the selectivity of BAPF. The activation energy of Mn0.5HPW/Mt and Mn1.0HPW/Mt is lower than that of HPW/Mt, leading to the preference for the BAPF formation. As the Mn content continually increased, all protons in phosphotungstic acid would be exchanged by Mn ions, increasing the activation energy of BAPF formation and decreasing the selectivity of BAPF formation. A similar study was carried out which reported that only strong Bronsted acid can activate ketone carbonyl group in fluorenone [9]. This could be due to the fact that Bronsted acid can activate the reactant molecules, thus reducing the activation energy and promoting the formation of BAPF. Compared with the catalyst without manganese modification, the apparent activation energy for formation of PFI increased from 35.8 kJ/mol to 42.4–44.9 kJ/mol when the catalyst was loaded with manganese. However, it seems that the apparent activation energy for formation of PFI did not change substantially by varying Mn content in the catalyst. The increase of apparent activation energy may be related to the formation of Lewis acid sites after the introduction of manganese ions: the unpaired electrons of aniline can occupy the empty orbitals of manganese ions, which reduces the probability of PFI formation by the reaction of unpaired electrons of aniline with ketone carbonyl. These results indicate that the manganese ions exerted strong effect on the apparent activation energy of the formation of BAPF and PFI. The difference of activation energy is an important factor to change the selectivity of the reaction. As a consequence, the product selectivity can be controlled by tuning the Mn loadings over MnxHPW/Mt. According to previous reports, the presence of strong protonic acid is a necessary condition for the catalytic formation of BAPF, and stronger acids lead to higher yields of BAPF [10]. However, the number of acid sites was not considered in these studies. In order to elucidate the influence of acid strength and acid site number on the BAPF synthesis, property characterization on MnxHPW/Mt, HSiW (Silicotungstic acid) /Mt, Zn1HPW/Mt (modified and supported methods are consistent with the previous paper) were conducted, specially the catalytic activity. The strength of acid sites was obtained by n-butylamine titration. As depicted in Fig. 15-a, the higher the acid strength of the catalyst, the higher the yield of BAPF, which is consistent with the previous report. However, the number of acid sites vary among different catalysts, which can have a substantial impact on the experimental results. The effect of the number of acid sites on the initial formation rate of BAPF and PFI is shown in Fig. 15-b. With the increase of the number of acid sites, the initial formation rate of BAPF increased significantly. HSiW/Mt, with the largest number of surface acid sites, exhibit the highest initial formation rate of BAPF as expected. In order to further explore the effect of acid strength on product selectivity. Fig. 15-c illustrates the effect of acid site strength of different catalysts on the initial rate of formation of BAPF and PFI. Due to the competition between the formation reactions of BAPF and PFI, difference in initial formation rates can indicate which reaction was dominant, thus improving the selectivity of the reaction. It can be seen that with the increase of acid strength on the catalyst surface, KBAPF: KPFI increases, which confirms that the increase of acid strength can improve the selectivity and yield of BAPF to a certain degree. The influence of the number of Bronsted acid sites on the initial formation rate of BAPF is shown in Fig. 15-d. The correlation between the number of Bronsted acid sites and the initial formation rate of BAPF follows a linear pattern: the increase of the number of Bronsted acid sites leads to a proportional increment of initial formation rate of BAPF, which suggests that the occurrence of Bronsted acid site plays a critical role in the catalytic formation of BAPF. Interestingly, the initial formation rate of by-product PFI exhibited an irregular trend. It has been reported that Bronsted acid can be a catalyst for the synthesis of imines [47]. However, with the increase of acid sites, the initial formation rate of PFI did not show an upward trend (Fig. 15-b and Fig. 11). Table 4 shows that the introduction of manganese ion can increase the apparent activation energy of PFI formation, which may inhibit the formation of PFI. In previous reports, strong Bronsted acid can increase the polarization of ketone carbonyl group and inhibit condensation reaction [48,49]. Moreover, the empty orbitals of transition metal ions can adsorb unpaired electrons and inhibit the side reactions caused by unpaired electrons [44]. In general, our study shows that the introduction of manganese ions to phosphotungstic acid can not only promote the protonation of crystal water, but also increase the number and intensity of Bronsted acid sites, which can improve the reaction rate and the selectivity of BAPF formation. In addition, the empty orbital of manganese ions can adsorb the unpaired electron of aniline, which can promote the formation of the reaction intermediate [50] and inhibit the formation of the by-product PFI caused by the unpaired electron. Under the combined effects by Bronsted acid and Lewis acid sites, the synthesis yield of BAPF was effectively increased. 4 Conclusions In this work, various Mn exchanged phosphotungstic acid supported on acid activated montmorillonite catalysts with intact Keggin ion structure were prepared. By evaluating the catalytic activity of BAPF synthesized by aniline and FK, this study showed that Mn ions were successfully introduced into the secondary structure of HPW. This approach can not only increase the number and strength of Bronsted acid sites, but also generate Lewis acid sites. Under the joint influence of these two types of acid sites, the selectivity and yield of BAPF synthesis can be engineered by changing the apparent activation energy of BAFP and PFI. The number of Bronsted acid sites can directly affect the formation rate of BAPF. High acidity promotes the selectivity formation of BAPF. Among these catalysts, Mn1HPW/ Mt has the highest catalytic activity with a yield of BAPF 82.9%. In addition, this catalyst is highly reusable. Its catalytic activity shows no noticeable decrease even after reusing thrice. Compared with conventional catalysts, Mn1HPW/Mt demonstrates promising potential of industrial application with minimal environmental footprint. coredata.dc:description: 9,9-Bis (4-aminophenyl) fluorene (BAPF) has been widely used in the research of high-performance polyimide and fluorene-based optical materials. However, it is challenging to mass production due to the limitation of catalytic technology. In this paper, various Mn exchanged phosphotungstic acid supported on montmorillonite catalysts were prepared. FESEM-EDX, FT-IR, Raman, XRD, XPS, BET, and NH3-TPD were deployed to characterize the catalyst material. BAPF, synthesized by 9-fluorenone and aniline, was used to evaluate the catalytic activities of catalysts under different conditions. The amount and strength of acid sites were changed by the number of Mn ions into phosphotungstic acid, which affected the catalytic activity of BAPF synthesis. The findings of this study show that the yield of BAPF can reach up to 82.9%. In addition, the catalyst can maintain a high catalytic activity after three times of recycling, which can effectively simplify the purification process and reduce the environmental footprint of BAPF manufacturing.
coredata.dc:title: Mn modified phosphotungstic acid, a highly selective catalyst for the synthesis of 9, 9-bis (4-aminophenyl) fluorene
